Graphene anchored palladium complex as efficient and recyclable catalyst in the Heck cross-coupling reaction Laura Fernández-García Matías Blanco Clara Blanco Patricia Álvarez Marcos Granda Ricardo Santamaría Rosa Menéndez ⁎ Instituto Nacional del Carbón, INCAR-CSIC, P.O. Box 73, 33080 Oviedo, Spain Instituto Nacional del Carbón INCAR-CSIC P.O. Box 73 Oviedo 33080 Spain ⁎ Corresponding author. Graphical abstract The immobilization of organometallic molecular catalysts on carbon nanomaterials requires an appropriate synthesis and functionalization methodology to yield active heterogeneous systems. In this work, molecular palladium complexes were synthesized on the aromatic network of a graphenic material employing diazonium chemistry and additional simple modifications to generate a bidentate coordination site for the palladium atoms. The presence of 0.2–0.25nm palladium(II) species on the surface of the graphenic layers was confirmed by XPS and HRTEM. The modified palladium-graphene hybrid was found to be active as catalyst in the cross-coupling Heck reaction between styrene or n-butyl acrylate with a wide range of aryl bromides substituted with different electron-acceptor and electron-withdrawing groups. The coupled products were obtained in good to excellent yields, at initial TOFs as high as 1.1s−1. In addition, the catalyst showed excellent cyclability and air stability, and was reused over 8 cycles without any loss of activity. Keywords Graphene Pd complexes Functionalization Heck cross-coupling Recyclability 1 Introduction Palladium-based homogeneous and heterogeneous catalysts are versatile tools that can be used to perform a large number of chemical and electrochemical reactions, such as hydrogenation/dehydrogenation, petroleum cracking or certain fuel-cell processes [1–5]. In addition, palladium organometallic compounds are known to be valuable catalysts for forming carbon–carbon bonds in cross coupling processes [6]. Numerous examples of the use of palladium complexes [7,8], or even palladium nanoparticles [9], have been reported in the literature to catalyze, for instance, Suzuki, Stille, Sonogashira reactions and Heck couplings [10,11]. All of these have not only contributed to clarifying the different steps involved in the reaction mechanism [12] but also to achieve total synthesis [13], biomolecules [14], drugs [15], and even chiral compounds [16] in both at laboratory and at industrial scale. Clearly, the high cost of these catalysts, the toxicity of the reaction residues and the complicated synthesis of the final catalyst precursors make it necessary to develop palladium catalysts which are easy to recover and that, cycle without losing their catalytic performance and activity [17]. Several studies in the literature deal with the anchorage of these catalytic species on different kinds of support, such as zeolites [18], metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) [19], polymers [20], activated carbons [21] or even carbon nanomaterials, i.e., carbon nanotubes and graphene [22]. However, these kinds of hybrid systems usually involve the use of palladium nanoparticles, and the number of examples of the covalent anchoring of palladium-based molecular catalysts on a carbonaceous support is very small. The heterogenization of an active palladium molecular cross coupling catalyst on graphenic materials could revolutionize the organic synthesis research due to the transfer of the outstanding properties of graphene (i.e., electronic transport, thermal conduction, etc.) to the active palladium center. Other authors have noted synergistic effects between graphenic materials and metallic nanoparticles in catalyzed chemical and electrochemical processes [23–25]. Therefore, graphene can take part, by electron-transfer assistance, in the necessary palladium oxidations and reductions in which the Heck cross-coupling-reaction mechanism is based. The unique properties of graphene and related materials, in relation to electron and thermal conductivity [26,27], intrinsic porosity and chemical inertness in most of the media [28] make these materials suitable for use as supports of molecular palladium catalytic species. Also, long established and well-tried functionalization routes for decorating the graphene lattice (1,3-dipolar addition, diazonium chemistry, the Bingle reaction) [29] make it possible to construct the catalyst precursor by applying few steps based on simple organic reactions as a way to establish accessible binding sites for immobilizing the palladium center on the surface of the material. In this way, leaching can be avoided, while, at the same time, a surface effect that enhances activity and also affords stability and cyclability to the catalytic system can be created [30]. In this study, the covalent surface decoration of a graphenic material with a nitrogen bidentate molecular palladium organometallic compound introduced into the aromatic scaffold by means of a three-step procedure is reported. First, diazonium chemistry is applied to obtain a nitrogen-based reactive point on the surface of the graphene that can be modified in a second reaction to achieve a nitrogen bidentate binding site for the palladium complex. This novel graphene-palladium hybrid system was employed as catalyst in a Heck cross coupling reaction between aryl bromides of different characteristics and suitable aliphatic or aromatic vinyl substrates in order to test the versatility of our system. The cyclability and air stability of the catalyst were also studied. 2 Materials and methods 2.1 Materials The solvents were distilled immediately prior to use from appropriate drying agents or obtained from a Solvent Purification System (Innovative Technologies). All the chemicals and the graphite were purchased from Aldrich. Reagent grade or better quality was employed in all of the experiments. Graphite oxide (GO) was prepared by a modified Hummers method as described elsewhere [46]. The graphenic material, TRGO, was prepared in a two-steps procedure. The first step consisted in the simultaneous exfoliation-reduction of GO in a home-made self-designed stainless-steel reactor by means of thermal treatment of the material at 300°C under an inert atmosphere [47]. The graphenic material was then annealed at 2000°C for 1h under an argon atmosphere to yield TRGO which was subsequently employed in the functionalization steps (Fig. 1 ). 2.2 Functionalization route The graphenic material TRGO was modified with a palladium organometallic complex in a three step procedure. In the first step, 0.15g of the graphenic material was suspended in 200mL of N-methyl-2-pyrrolidone (NMP), subjected to 10min of sonication and then mixed with 5.18g (37.5mmol) of 4-nitroaniline and 10.1mL (75mmol) of isopenthyl nitrite. The reaction mixture was magnetically stirred at 85°C for 1h. Then, the solid product was thoroughly washed with dimethyl formamide (DMF) (3×100mL), methanol (3×100mL), ammonium hydroxide (2×200mL), Milli-Q water (2×200mL), methanol (2×100mL), ethyl acetate (2×100mL) and diethyl ether (1×50mL). The resultant sample was labelled TRGO-NO2 . The nitro group (0.125g of material obtained in the previous step) was deprotected by reduction with tin (II) chloride (0.375g, 2mmol) in a 200mL mixture of boiling (1:1) tetrahydrofuran (THF) − ethanol for 24h. The reaction crude was washed with a 0.5M HCl solution (8×50mL), Milli-Q water till neutral pH, a 0.5M solution of NaOH (8×50mL), Milli-Q water till neutral pH, THF (4×50mL) and ether (1×50mL). The resulting sample was labelled TRGO-NH2 . The second step was based on the reaction of the a aniline unit (0.125g of the material obtained in the preceding step) with picolinaldehide (0.386mL, 0.4mmol) catalyzed by introducing a drop of formic acid into 200mL of ethanol at refluxing conditions for 48h. After the reaction, the sample was washed with 6×50mL of ethanol, 6×50mL of dichloromethane (DCM) and 1×50mL of ether. The resultant sample was labelled TRGO-NPy. Finally, the palladium complex was formed by reacting 0.1g of TRGO-NPy with 0.05g (0.13mmol) of palladium(II) acetate and KCl (0.0193g, 0.26mmol) in 100mL of acetonitrile. The reaction was held for 5h under reflux conditions. The sample was then washed with 6×50mL of acetonitrile and ether, and labelled TRGO-NPy-Pd. 2.3 Catalytic reactions In a typical experiment, the vinyl substrate (styrene derivatives or butyl acrylate derivatives, 1mmol), the aryl bromide (1mmol), Na2CO3 (2mmol), solvent (DMF, 4mL) and the catalyst (0.3mol%, 15.6mg of sample) were introduced into a 25mL Schlenk round-bottomed flask. The reaction was held at 140°C for the desired time (Table 1 ). Aliquots were taken and subjected to thin-layer chromatography (TLC) or NMR spectroscopy in order to follow the progress of the reaction. Once the reaction was completed, the crude product was washed with water, extracted three times with ether, dried over anhydrous MgSO4 and concentrated under reduced pressure. Purification by recrystallization in ethanol or by flash chromatography in silica (hexane:ethyl acetate 10:1) yielded the final product. The TRGO-NPy-Pd sample was recovered by centrifugation and washed three times with 20mL of acetone. In the E-stilbene synthesis, several catalytic cycles were performed without adding any fresh catalyst precursor. The last cycle at least was carried out without an inert atmosphere. 2.4 Characterization methods Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) images were obtained on a JEOL JEM-2100F transmission electron microscope, equipped with a field-emission-gun (FEG) operating at 200kV and an Oxford Instruments Energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDX) probe. The samples were prepared by casting a few drops of 1mgmL−1 ethanol suspensions over carbon grids. Raman spectra were recorded on an Invia Renishaw microspectrometer (50×) with the laser source set to 532nm. Fourier-Transformed Infrared (FTIR) spectra were recorded on a Nicolet 8700 FTIR spectrometer (Thermo Scientific) fitted with a DFT (deuterated triglycine sulfate) detector, operating in transmission mode on KBr pellets. The X-ray photoemission spectroscopy (XPS) spectra were recorded using a SPECS system operating under a pressure of 10−7 Pa with a Mg Kα X-ray source. Oxygen functional groups within the graphenic material were quantified by deconvoluting the high resolution C1s XPS peak and employing Gaussian and Lorentzian functions [48]. Nitrogenized species were analyzed with respect to the N1s band of the XPS spectra. The amount of palladium present in the samples was determined by means of Inductively Coupled Plasma Mass Spectrometry (ICP-MS) on an Agilent 7700× instrument. The samples were digested following a method described elsewhere [49]. Briefly, 30mg of sample was treated with 5mL of a mixture of concentrated nitric and hydrochloric acid (3:1 ratio) at 180°C for 3h under microwave irradiation. NMR spectra were recorded on a Bruker Advance 400 spectrometer operating at 400.16MHz (1H). NMR chemical shifts are reported in ppm relative to tetramethylsilane and referenced to partially deuterated solvent resonances. Coupling constants (J) are given in hertz. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Synthesis of the graphenic material Graphenic materials are prepared by applying thermal flash treatment to a graphite oxide (GO) synthesized by a modified Hummers method, as described elsewhere [46]. The focus of this study was the reconstruction of the aromatic scaffold on the graphenic layers. Consequently, a high temperature thermal annealing process was applied after the thermal treatment of the GO, as a result of which TRGO was obtained (Fig. 1). The Raman spectrum of TGRO (Fig. 2 a) shows a typical D/G/2D bands pattern which corroborates the graphenic nature of the material. The shape of the spectrum confirms the reconstruction of the aromatic lattice, with a very low I D/I G ratio (I D/I G =0.21), and a pronounced second order spectrum, typical of a non-defective exfoliated-graphene material [31]. This was also evidenced by the XPS analysis of the sample, which showed a C/O ratio of 498 and an amount of Csp2 of 84.0%, indicating the successful reconstruction of the aromatic lattice, that is backed up by the deconvolution of the XPS C1s peak (Appendix A). Residual oxygen groups were mainly hydroxylic functions (6.0%), while epoxy and carboxylic groups were almost totally absent (0.6 and 0.0% respectively). TEM images of the graphenic material used in this study show the classical wrinkled appearance characteristic of graphenic materials obtained by thermal reduction (Appendix A). 3.2 Decoration of the material with the palladium complex Reconstruction of the sp2 aromatic lattice of the graphenic material allows functionalization by diazonium chemistry methods, as reported elsewhere [32]. Additional chemical modifications of the decorated units can be made in order to obtain the final catalyst precursor, on the basis of a suitable choice of the aniline [33]. In this way, the in situ formation of a diazonium salt from the p-nitroaniline amino group, followed by the thermal release of nitrogen and the entrapment of the nitrobenzene radical yields a functionalized graphenic layer TRGO-NO2 (Fig. 1). Deprotection of the nitro group by applying a standard reduction protocol based on tin chloride [20] yields the amino-functionalized graphenic material TRGO-NH2 . The introduction of the nitrobenzene unit and its subsequent reduction to an amino group was characterized by Raman and XPS spectroscopy. An increase in the I D/I G ratio (from 0.21 to 0.32) in the Raman spectra of TRGO-NO2 was detected (Fig. 2a) as a consequence of the generation of sp3 carbon due to the formation of a new CC bond between the graphenic layer and the diazonium salt [32]. In addition, the I D/I G ratio of the reduced sample was unchanged, which indicates that reduction took place only in the nitro group and not in the carbon nanomaterial, as confirmed by the increase in the nitrogen content of the functionalized samples. The parent graphenic material TRGO contained a negligible amount of nitrogen (0.0%), which is increased to 1.2% in TRGO-NO2 , and this value was maintained in the reduced sample TRGO-NH2 (1.2%). In addition, nitrogenized species were identified. A shift in the maxima of the N1s bands occurred (Fig. 2b), varying from 406.2eV in TRGO-NO2 , corresponding exclusively to the NO2 group, to lower energies of 399.5eV in TRGO-NH2 . These data fully agree with the positive reduction from a nitro to an amino group [34]. As can also be seen in Fig. 2b, the parent material TRGO only gives a noise curve due to its null nitrogen content. The presence of the nitro and amino groups in both samples was also corroborated by FTIR spectroscopy (Appendix A), the characteristic scissors bands at 1600–1400cm−1 of the NO bonds had vanished while a broad band at higher wavenumbers, ∼3200cm−1 appeared corresponding to the NH bonds [20]. TRGO-NH2 reacted with picolinaldehide to generate the imino-functionalized material TRGO-NPy. Finally, individual palladium units were trapped by the two donor nitrogen atoms covalently attached to the graphenic material surface, resulting in the final hybrid material TRGO-NPy-Pd. ICP-MS analysis revealed that 2.4% of palladium was incorporated to the graphenic material, which is in agreement with the nitrogen content of the previous samples. In addition, 0.2–0.25 of nm electron-dense regions were found to be attached to the surface of the graphenic layers in the TEM observations (Fig. 3 ). Although larger particles were also detected, possibly due to beam irradiation under high vacuum inside the microscope chamber, the size of the spots was in agreement with molecular complexes. Similar observations had been previously reported for molecular iridium complexes supported on graphene oxide and related thermally reduced graphenic material [35]. EDX analysis confirmed the presence of palladium species (Appendix A), and the oxidation state, as determined by XPS, corresponds to palladium(II) species (Fig. 3 inset), while two maxima were obtained at 335.7 and 341.0eV, [36] evidencing that the organometallic palladium complex proposed in Fig. 1 anchored onto the graphenic material surface. 3.3 Catalytic activity The palladium hybrid material TRGO-NPy-Pd was tested as catalyst precursor in the CC cross coupling Heck reaction between aryl bromides and vinyl substrates (Fig. 4 ) [37]. Firstly, the catalytic performance of the hybrid material was tested on a model reaction involving styrene (1mmol) and bromobenzene (1mmol), with an excess of Na2CO3 (2mmol) acting as base in boiling DMF. It is worth noting that in the experimental setup used, neither phosphine nor any other donor ligand was employed to stabilize the palladium center. With a catalyst loading of 0.3mol %, the reaction proceeded smoothly, yielding the desired product E-stilbene, in a high isolated yield (97%) after 18h of reaction. As expected, the reaction performed without using a palladium source, employing TRGO-NPy as catalyst, led to a negligible conversion (see Appendix A). Moreover, the heterogeneous system was more active than the homogeneous catalyst based on palladium acetate test performed under the same conditions for comparative purposes. In the homogeneous reaction, only 75% of isolated yield was obtained after 24h of reaction. Heterogenization of the catalyst, combined with the surface effect afforded by the graphenic material [38] and the homogeneous dispersion of palladium centers throughout the graphene layer (see Fig. 3) may have been responsible for enhancing the catalytic activity. A kinetic profile was constructed to obtain a better understanding of the system. 0.1mL aliquots were taken at different reaction times, and analyzed by TLC and 1H NMR spectroscopy. As can be seen in Fig. 5 , no induction period was observed following the thermal equilibration of the reactants. The formation of E-stilbene was detected immediately, with TRGO-NPy-Pd achieving an initial TOF of 1.08s−1 (Table 1), which is higher than that of other palladium systems used for the Heck reaction reported in the literature, such as metallic nanoparticles supported on phosphates [39], silica matrixes [40], polymers [41], zeolites [42] and ionic liquids [43], and even homogenous systems [44]. Moreover, a conversion of more than 90% was obtained after 3h of reaction, and complete saturation was reached after 5h. It should also be mentioned that the model reaction was studied using a substrate (bromobenzene) without any electron-donor or electron-withdrawing groups that might have modified the electronic density of the system. An important feature of a heterogeneous catalyst is its capacity to be reused. Consequently, the recyclability of the system based on the Heck model reaction was tested. After each run, the black solids were recovered by centrifugation, washed three times with 20mL of acetone and then dried under vacuum. The recovered product was subjected to 8 catalytic cycles using for every single transformation a fresh reaction mixture but without adding any fresh catalyst precursor. Recycled TRGO-NPy-Pd exhibited similar conversions to the fresh catalyst (Fig. 6 ). However, a slight decrease in activity was observed after the fifth cycle, possibly due to a marginal loss of material in each of the recovery steps. Nevertheless, no leaching of palladium was detected by the ICP measurements. In addition, the catalyst remained stable under air due to the fact that a similar conversion of E-stilbene to those of the preceding experiments was achieved in the final cycle without using an inert atmosphere (Fig. 6). To study the versatility of the catalyst, several reactions were performed employing electron-donor and electron-withdrawing groups which modify the electronic density of the aryl bromide, such as Me, CHO, NO2, OMe, CF3 and even brominated pyridine. In addition, the scope of the catalyst was tested using aryl and vinyl substrates with styryl and acrylic skeletons to preserve the double bond. The results are depicted in Table 1. In general, all the reactions with styryl substrates (entries 1–7) were very clean and the corresponding white (or yellow, entry 6) solids were obtained in good to excellent yields within 1.5–10h. However, the butyl acrylate reactions produced lower yields and required longer times than the styrene-based ones. In addition, in the case of the aliphatic substrate, more byproducts were obtained, which were removed by flash chromatographic purification instead of using the simple recrystallization procedure applied to the stilbene derivatives. Interestingly, both pyridine couplings (entries 7, 14) gave rise to a very smooth reaction, from which a clean final product was obtained in a very short period of time, evidencing the versatility of the catalyst. In relation to the chemistry of the reaction, the electron-withdrawing groups required the shortest reaction times when both substrates were employed. It has frequently been reported in the literature that the Heck reaction achieves better results when the molecules are aromatic, and also, when the electron density is withdrawn from the carbon bonded to the halide [45], in agreement with our results. In light with these findings it is not surprising that electron-donating groups required the longest times to complete their reactions. After the reactions, the catalysts were subjected to another chemical and microscopic analysis (Fig. 7 ). No differences were found in the oxidation state of palladium in the XPS Pd3d spectrum. The same peaks at 335.7 and 341.0eV were obtained as before the catalytic reactions. In addition, the electron dense regions in the TEM corresponding to the palladium complexes did not increase in size. 0.2–0.25nm was detected for each region, in agreement with the data for the fresh graphenic catalyst. 4 Conclusions It has been demonstrated that the preparation of an active palladium-based molecular catalyst on the basal planes of a high-temperature reduced graphenic material is possible by applying diazonium chemistry, followed by some straightforward modifications reactions to yield covalently supported palladium complexes. The modified graphenic material was tested as a catalyst in the Heck cross coupling reaction, where it showed an excellent activity, a high recyclability and also good air stability. Furthermore, it was able to perform CC coupling in a wide range of different substrates with either electron donor or withdrawing groups, and even with aliphatic and aromatic compounds. In this study, the heterogeneous catalyst was found to be more active than the homogenous palladium complex. The good catalytic activity shown by our catalytic system combined with the fact that it is easy to prepare and the graphenic material is very stable could make our nanohybrid material an affordable and competitive alternative to conventional catalysts in organic synthesis research. coredata.dc:description: The immobilization of organometallic molecular catalysts on carbon nanomaterials requires an appropriate synthesis and functionalization methodology to yield active heterogeneous systems. In this work, molecular palladium complexes were synthesized on the aromatic network of a graphenic material employing diazonium chemistry and additional simple modifications to generate a bidentate coordination site for the palladium atoms. The presence of 0.2–0.25nm palladium(II) species on the surface of the graphenic layers was confirmed by XPS and HRTEM. The modified palladium-graphene hybrid was found to be active as catalyst in the cross-coupling Heck reaction between styrene or n-butyl acrylate with a wide range of aryl bromides substituted with different electron-acceptor and electron-withdrawing groups. The coupled products were obtained in good to excellent yields, at initial TOFs as high as 1.1s−1. In addition, the catalyst showed excellent cyclability and air stability, and was reused over 8 cycles without any loss of activity.
coredata.dc:title: Graphene anchored palladium complex as efficient and recyclable catalyst in the Heck cross-coupling reaction
